title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: GitHub API
text: Use gh() function access API endpoints. endpoints listed documentation. first argument gh() endpoint. can just copy paste API endpoints documentation. Note leading slash must included well. https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#list-repositories---user can copy paste GET /users/{username}/repos gh() call. E.g. JSON result sent API converted R object. Parameters can passed extra arguments. E.g.
code: library(gh) my_repos <- gh("GET /users/{username}/repos", username = "gaborcsardi") vapply(my_repos, "[[", "", "name") #>  [1] "after"                "alexr"                "all.primer.tutorials" #>  [4] "altlist"              "argufy"               "ask"                  #>  [7] "async"                "autobrew-bundler"     "BCEA"                 #> [10] "BH"                   "bigrquerystorage"     "brew-big-sur"         #> [13] "brokenPackage"        "butcher"              "checkinstall"         #> [16] "cli"                  "covrlabs"             "csg"                  #> [19] "css"                  "curl"                 "cv"                   #> [22] "cyclocomp"            "cynkrablog"           "DBItest"              #> [25] "debian-repo"          "disposables"          "dotenv"               #> [28] "falsy"                "finmix"               "foobar" my_repos <- gh(   "/users/{username}/repos",   username = "gaborcsardi",   sort = "created") vapply(my_repos, "[[", "", "name") #>  [1] "nanonext"              "winget-pkgs"           "gon"                   #>  [4] "PlotR"                 "miniparquet"           "LDAvis"                #>  [7] "ragg"                  "TreeDist"              "mmrm"                  #> [10] "SKFCPD"                "RSiena2"               "rsiena"                #> [13] "ReadStat"              "libxls"                "covrlabs"              #> [16] "nanodbc"               "odbc"                  "r-dev-web"             #> [19] "homebrew-core-big-sur" "brew-big-sur"          "scripts"               #> [22] "format"                "bigrquerystorage"      "autobrew-bundler"      #> [25] "homebrew-cran"         "cv"                    "playground3"           #> [28] "cynkrablog"            "usethis"               "minimaxApprox"

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: extremely minimal client. need know API able use client. function : Try substitute listed parameter endpoint, using {parameter} notation. GET request (default), add listed parameters query parameters. GET request, send parameters request body, JSON. Convert response R list using jsonlite::fromJSON().

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
code: gh(   endpoint,   ...,   per_page = NULL,   .per_page = NULL,   .token = NULL,   .destfile = NULL,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .api_url = NULL,   .method = "GET",   .limit = NULL,   .accept = "application/vnd.github.v3+json",   .send_headers = NULL,   .progress = TRUE,   .params = list(),   .max_wait = 600,   .max_rate = NULL )

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: endpoint GitHub API endpoint. Must one following forms: METHOD path, e.g. GET /rate_limit, path, e.g. /rate_limit, METHOD url, e.g. GET https://api.github.com/rate_limit, url, e.g. https://api.github.com/rate_limit. method supplied, use .method, defaults "GET". ... Name-value pairs giving API parameters. matched endpoint placeholders, sent query parameters GET requests, JSON body POST requests. one unnamed parameter, raw vector, JSON encoded, sent raw data, . can used example add assets releases. Named NULL values silently dropped. GET requests, named NA values trigger error. methods, named NA values included body request, JSON null. per_page, .per_page Number items return per page. omitted, substituted max(.limit, 100) .limit set, otherwise determined API (never greater 100). .token Authentication token. Defaults gh_token(). .destfile Path write response disk. NULL (default), response processed returned object. path given, response written disk form sent. gh writes response temporary file, renames file .destfile request successful. name temporary file created adding -<random>.gh-tmp suffix , <random> ASCII string random characters. gh removes temporary file error. .overwrite .destfile provided, whether overwrite existing file.  Defaults FALSE. error happens original file kept. .api_url Github API url (default: https://api.github.com). Used endpoint just contains path. Defaults GITHUB_API_URL environment variable set. .method HTTP method use explicitly supplied endpoint. .limit Number records return. can used instead manual pagination. default NULL, means defaults GitHub API used. can set number request (less) records, also Inf request records. Note, request many records, multiple GitHub API calls used get , can take potentially long time. .accept value Accept HTTP header. Defaults "application/vnd.github.v3+json" . Accept given .send_headers, used. parameter can used provide custom media type, order access preview feature API. .send_headers Named character vector header field values (except Authorization, handled via .token). can used override augment default User-Agent header: "https://github.com/r-lib/gh". .progress Whether show progress indicator calls need one HTTP request. .params Additional list parameters append .... easier use ... parameters list already. .max_wait Maximum number seconds wait rate limited. Defaults 10 minutes. .max_rate Maximum request rate requests per second. Set automatically throttle requests.

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: Answer API gh_response object, also list. Failed requests generate R error. Requests generate raw response return raw vector.

This can be easily done using `reduce` function from `purrr` package:\r\n```{r}\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(purrr)\r\n\r\ndf1 <- tibble(\r\n  index = 1:4,\r\n  values = 5:8\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf2 <- tibble(\r\n  index = 2:4,\r\n  first = 6:8\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf3 <- tibble(\r\n  index = 3:4,\r\n  second = 7:8\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf_list <- list(df1, df2, df3)\r\ndf_join <- df_list |> \r\n  reduce(left_join, by = \"index\")\r\n```  \r\n\r\nBut taken into consideration that `bind_cols` from `dplyr` already allows working with lists of data frames I think it could be a great feature the possibility of joining "created_at": "2024-08-28T17:38:43Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-09-02T15:44:47Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "There's currently no quick way to extract both the first and last rows of a grouped data frame. This is useful if, for example, you want to identify the limits from a range of values in an ordered sequence.\r\n\r\nCurrently, the workflow looks something like:\r\n\r\n```\r\n### Option one:\r\n\r\ndf_1 <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        slice_head()\r\n\r\ndf_2 <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        slice_tail()\r\n\r\ndata <- rbind(data_1, data_2)\r\n\r\n### Option two:\r\n\r\ndf <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        filter(row_number()==1 | row_number()==n()) \r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe following code combines existing dplyr functionality to make this operation more intuitive:\r\n```\r\nslice_ends <- function(data){\r\n\r\n    data_1 <- data %>%\r\n        slice_head()\r\n\r\n    data_2 <- data %>%\r\n        slice_tail()\r\n\r\n    rbind(data_1, data_2)\r\n\r\n}\r\n\r\n# To give:\r\n\r\ndf <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        slice_ends()\r\n```\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "This is related to #7074. `if_any()` is now supposed to return `FALSE` when no inputs are provided as per #7072. This works correctly inside `filter` but not `mutate`.\r\n\r\n```r\r\niris %>% \r\n  filter(if_any(c(), \\(x) x  > 4000)) # returns no rows as expected\r\n\r\niris %>%\r\n    mutate(z = if_any(c(),  \\(x) x  > 4000)) # incorrectly returns all TRUE\r\n```\r\n\r\nApologies if I misunderstood something.\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "created_at": "2024-08-01T23:19:37Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-08-01T23:19:37Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "If `x` is not a column name in data frame `d`, then `pull(d, x)` attempts to look up the value of `x` in the environment instead of returning NULL or an error as I would expect. \r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\n# Create two env-variables\r\nd <- data.frame(x = \"ex\", y = \"why\")\r\nx <- \"y\"\r\n\r\n# As expected, pulls the data-variable `x`\r\npull(d, x)\r\n\r\n# If name `x` does not exist in `d`,\r\nd <- select(d, -x)\r\n\r\n# Not expected: finds the env-variable `x`, pulls the data-variable `y`\r\npull(d, x)\r\n\r\n# Exactly as if we had written pull(d, y)\r\nidentical(pull(d, x), pull(d, y))\r\n```\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7064/reactions", #> \"Session aborted\" when using the filter function on a dataframe that was produced by using rbind on dataframe that had the rowwise grouping. Ungrouping before filtering stop the issue, but the crash make it weird and hard to fix.\r\n\r\nThis code should reproduce the crash\r\n```r\r\n# install.packages(c(\"tidyr\", \"dplyr\"))\r\nlibrary(tidyr)\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ntest <- data.frame(\"col1\" = c(1,2,3,4,5,85,74,5,32,6,8), \"col\" = c(\"A\",\"B\",\"B\",\"B\",\"A\",\"C\",\"A\",\"C\",\"B\",\"A\",\"A\"))\r\ntest <- rowwise(test)\r\ntest <- rbind(test, test)\r\nfilter(test, col == \"A\")  #crashes\r\n\r\n# R version 4.4.1 (2024-06-14)\r\n# had same issue on 4.3\r\n# dplyr 1.1.4\r\n```\r\n\r\nThanks for your time !", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "Sometimes, when doing data wrangling, you need to apply functions not only on multiple columns, but also on multiple pairs of columns. This is what the [`{dplyover}`](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover) package allows with its [`across2()` and `across2x()` functions](https://timteafan.github.io/dplyover/reference/across2.html):\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# remotes::install_github(\"TimTeaFan/dplyover\")\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(dplyover)\r\n\r\niris %>% \r\n  group_by(Species) %>%\r\n  summarise(across2x(starts_with(\"Sepal\"), starts_with(\"Petal\"), cor))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 5\r\n#>   Species   Sepal.Length_Petal.L…¹ Sepal.Length_Petal.W…² Sepal.Width_Petal.Le…³\r\n#>   <fct>                      <dbl>                  <dbl>                  <dbl>\r\n#> 1 setosa                     0.267                  0.278                  0.178\r\n#> 2 versicol…                  0.754                  0.546                  0.561\r\n#> 3 virginica                  0.864                  0.281                  0.401\r\n#> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​Sepal.Length_Petal.Length, ²​Sepal.Length_Petal.Width,\r\n#> #   ³​Sepal.Width_Petal.Length\r\n#> # ℹ 1 more variable: Sepal.Width_Petal.Width <dbl>\r\n\r\ncor(iris[1:50,]$Sepal.Length, iris[1:50,]$Petal.Length)\r\n#> [1] 0.2671758\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-07-17 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\nThe creation of the `{dplyover}` began with this [issue](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4834), which –at that time– recommended putting these features in an adjacent package. \r\n\r\n`{dplyover}` has really saved me and my colleagues a huge amount of time. However, it is not on CRAN, some bugs [[1](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/21), [2](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/23)] have been found, enhancement in the `{dplyr}` package are [not currently supported](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/1), and the last commit is 3 years old.\r\n\r\nDo you think these really useful functions could be included in the `{dplyr}` package? #>     "number": 7048, #>     "title": "`dplyr_reconstruct` can create data.table with corrupted secondary index", #>     "user": { #>       "login": "ZIBOWANGKANGYU", #>       "id": 39108796, #>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjM5MTA4Nzk2", #>       "avatar_url": "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/39108796?v=4", #>       "gravatar_id": "", #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/users/ZIBOWANGKANGYU", #>       "html_url": "https://github.com/ZIBOWANGKANGYU", #>       "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/ZIBOWANGKANGYU/followers", #> "created_at": "2024-07-03T23:56:10Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-07-05T13:04:02Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "## Problem\r\n\r\nThanks @AMDraghici for your suggestions!\r\n\r\nFor example, in `bind_rows`, if the first input is a `data.table`, the output table can have corrupt indexing due to how the underlying `dplyr_reconstruct` function deals with the attributes of the two inputs\r\n\r\n## Reprex\r\n\r\nThe example below shows that the index attribute can be incorrect for the output. \r\n\r\n```r\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(5, 2:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"c\") # Create a data.table\r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil. This is necessary for the subset error below to happen in data.table. But it is not necessary to re-produce the corrupted index. \r\n> a[cola == 4] # Give data.table a secondary index (\"cola\" column) by auto-indexing\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$index # The secondary index is set correctly\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, colb = 2, colc=3, cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::bind_rows(list(a,b))\r\n> \r\n> combined # combined is a data.table, with 5 rows\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     5 0.5535855 0.6024416      c\r\n2:     2 0.3407051 0.9291365      c\r\n3:     3 0.5007208 0.6823528      c\r\n4:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n5:    -1 2.0000000 3.0000000      d\r\n> \r\n> attributes(combined)$index # Wrong! length of secondary index is only 4\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 4 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold # Wrong! The last row of combined should be returned\r\n> combined\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola       colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>      <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     1 0.83105427 0.4214379      c\r\n2:     2 0.05702599 0.1354883      c\r\n3:     3 0.63866251 0.1644736      c\r\n4:     4 0.21441544 0.2198251      c\r\n5:    -1 2.00000000 3.0000000      d\r\n```\r\n## Cause\r\n\r\nIn the `bind_rows` function, `dplyr_reconstruct` is used to set attributes for the output dataframe. \r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/R/bind-rows.R#L79\r\n\r\n```r\r\nout <- dplyr_reconstruct(out, first)\r\n```\r\nLooking at the `dplyr_reconstruct` function, it is essentially giving all attributes other than `names` and `row.names` in `template_` to `data`.\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/src/reconstruct.cpp#L36 \r\n\r\nIn the case above, all attributes of `first` (which has four rows), including index are given to `out`, which has five rows. This causes the problem. \r\n\r\n## Impact\r\n\r\nBecause the `data.table` produced by `bind_rows` has corrupted secondary index, the filter functionality of `data.table` is skipping some rows when filtering by the index column. \r\nAlso, I found that this problem is not limited to `bind_rows`. Other `dplyr` functions that calls `dplyr_reconstruct` can result in data.tables with corrupted secondary index. For example, the `full_join` function can also produce unexpected results due to corrupted secondary index.  \r\n\r\n```\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(1:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil\r\n> a[cola == 3]\r\n       cola         colb         colc      cold\r\n   <int>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     3 0.9968646 0.8137836      d\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, cole = \"e\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::full_join(a, b, by = \"cola\")\r\n> \r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 5 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold,cole\r\n```", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "created_at": "2024-06-26T19:48:59Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-06-26T19:48:59Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "See https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7044\r\n\r\nIn particular, note that `arrange(df, x)` will sort `x` using the C locale if it is a character vector. But `arrange(df, -desc(x))` (i.e. invert the `desc()` call, giving you the original order in theory) will sort `x` using the user's locale.\r\n\r\nNormally a call like `desc(x)` is recognized and we don't even actually call `desc()` under the hood, we translate it to a `\"desc\"` value for the `directions` argument of `vec_order_radix()`, but in this case the `-` interferes and we actually evaluate the call.\r\n\r\nThat ends up calling `desc()` which does `-xtfrm(x)`, and `xtfrm()` ends up using `base::order(x)`, utilizing the user's locale.\r\n\r\nI don't think we should remove usage of `xtfrm()` in `desc()`, since that is a generic that people have probably written S3 methods for, but maybe we can have special behavior for unclassed character vectors where it utilized `vec_rank()` instead (which uses the C locale)? It would not be a perfect fix, but it may be good enough.", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7045/reactions", #> "created_at": "2024-06-12T05:52:35Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-06-12T05:52:35Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Should we guarantee that the functions used in a rowwise `mutate()` or `summarize()` or `reframe()` always see length-one input? This is currently the case for everything but empty input, which creates a corner case to be worked around in user code. The example below shows `mutate()`, but the behavior is very similar for `summarize()` and `reframe()`\r\n\r\n``` r\r\noptions(conflicts.policy = list(warn = FALSE))\r\n\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1L) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1:3) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> [1] 2\r\n#> [1] 3\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n#> 2     2          2\r\n#> 3     3          3\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\n# Should this print `NA_integer_` ?\r\ntibble(a = integer()) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> integer(0)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#> # ℹ 2 variables: a <int>, print(a) <int>\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-06-12 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7039/reactions", #> "created_at": "2024-06-02T23:02:29Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-06-03T19:17:48Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "draft": false, #>     "pull_request": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/pulls/7038", #>       "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/7038", #>       "diff_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/7038.diff", #>       "patch_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/7038.patch", #>       "merged_at": {} #>     }, #>     "body": "Hi @hadley and @DavisVaughan,\r\n\r\nThis merge request aims to align the mutate functionality with that of transmute. Presently, the documentation states that the equivalent of transmute is mutate(.keep=\"none\"). However, it's important to note that this function retains the column order, unlike transmute.\r\n\r\nAfter reviewing the bug reported here: https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6861, I concur that there should be a fifth variant of keep, named \"transmute.\"\r\n\r\nThis proposal should also be implemented in the following tidyverse libraries:\r\n- [ ] [dtplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dtplyr)  \r\n- [ ] [dbplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr):  https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr/pull/1508\r\n\r\nAnd in the following third party libraries:\r\n- [ ] [duckplyr](https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr): https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr/pull/176\r\n- [ ] [arrow](https://github.com/apache/arrow/r)\r\n- [ ] [tidypolars](https://github.com/etiennebacher/tidypolars)\r\n\r\nThis change opens the possibility of un-superseded transmute. For example, you could implement that when a user calls transmute, it internally executes mutate(.keep=\"transmute\"). This would greatly benefit veteran users who have extensively used transmute in their projects. Additionally, it improves code readability, as a simple transmute call is clearer than mutate(.keep=\"transmute\").\r\n\r\nBelow I leave an example comparing transmute with mutate(.keep = \"transmute\")\r\n\r\n```\r\nexample <- tibble(\r\n  group = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\"),\r\n  old = c(1, 2, 3, 4)\r\n)\r\n\r\n# transmute --------------------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% transmute(\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") --------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% mutate(\r\n  .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + transmute ---------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  transmute(\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") ---------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\", by = ...) ----------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>%  \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    .by = \"group\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n  )\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nRegards,\r\n\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #> #>     "number": 7028, #>     "title": "FR: allow `pick()` to rename in `distinct()` + some thoughts about `arrange()` allowing renaming.", #>     "user": { #>       "login": "olivroy", #>       "id": 52606734, #>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjUyNjA2NzM0", #>       "avatar_url": "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/52606734?v=4", #>       "gravatar_id": "", #>       "url":  "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/received_events", #>       "type": "User", #>       "site_admin": false #>     }, #>     "labels": [], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2024-05-18T17:37:23Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-08-20T14:46:11Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "This would be useful in packages to avoid cran warnings as `pick()` is the new preferred way.\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\noptions(lifecycle_verbosity = \"error\")\r\nmtcars <- utils::head(mtcars, n = 6)\r\n# distinct -----------\r\n# renaming generally makes a lot of sense, as distinct is like `transmute(...)` + `distinct()`\r\n# consider this in EDA\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = vs)\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\n# as it is equivalent to: (to avoid cran warnings)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = .data$vs)\r\n# Before dplyr 1.1, `across()` was recommended, which works, but .fns = NULL is soft-deprecated.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# The alternative when you may not know variable names in a package\r\n# with `pick()` should therefore work too, but errors.\r\n# I think it should work\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `distinct()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n# Similarly:\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n\r\n# I would expect distinct() and transmute()  + distinct() to be same as above (and it is!) ---\r\n# transmute() is still very useful as it is mutate + select in a single call)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = .data$vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n# I think this should be allowed.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#> Error in `transmute()`:\r\n#> ℹ In argument: `pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nNow comes `arrange()`...\r\n\r\n## arrange() \r\n\r\nWhile I believe `distinct()` should accept renaming under any circonstances, I believe that accepting renaming in `arrange()` is inconsistent, as `arrange()` ignores it silently. renaming (or attempt to do so) should error in all cases for `arrange()`. \r\n\r\nHowever, it behaves exactly the same as `distinct()`. (so it is consistent in that sense, but ignores )\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# arrange() is same as distinct() but silently ignores renaming...\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = .data$vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# this rightfully errors!\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `arrange()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `..1 = pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe a soft-deprecation warning would be desirable for attempting to rename in arrange()\r\nSomething like names ignored, use unnamed, or remove name, or create this variable with mutate() to keep it.\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\n#  A beginner may think that this will create the variable as nothing is stopping them.\r\ny <- mtcars |> arrange(x = vs, y = desc(disp))\r\n\r\n## later tries to access the variable and gets a warning or even worse. This confusing data frame.\r\n\r\ny |> mutate(z = y **2) # gets very bad output!\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n# Suggestions for signaling that `arrange()` ignores renaming.\r\n\r\n1. (preferred) soft-deprecation warning\r\n \r\nsomething like: named input is ignored in arrange(). Please omit them.\r\nin all_of(named_external_selection)  the adjustment required would just be all_of(unname(named_external_selection))\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nx |> arrange(new_var = var)\r\n# now\r\nx |> arrange(var)\r\n```\r\n\r\nif you want to create a new variable or rename, use `rename()` or `mutate()`, as arrange silently ignores names provided.\r\n\r\n\r\n## using the case of tidyselect deprecation of external selection as an example\r\n\r\nit seems pretty similar as the deprecation of `select(.data$vs)` in favour of `select(\"vs\")` + requiring any_of() all_of(). it ended up just increasing\r\ngeneral consitency of code base, and improve clarity.\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Before when you read this in someone else's code (i.e. with no context)\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(vs)\r\n# you had no idea if the data had a `vs` column, or `vs` was an external vector\r\n# the alternative made everything much clearer.\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(all_of(vs))\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nMy proposed change would force users to remove this potentially misleading code\r\n have the benefit that no one would question if the resulting data frame has a `x` column or not.\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6980 would be addressed automatically as part of this idea. i.e no longer allowing named selection would act a bit like a `check_dots_used()` condition\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# this code is clearer about what it does (and gives the same result as above)\r\n# proposed\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(vs)\r\n```\r\n\r\n2. Breaking change (respect renaming in arrange() i.e. arrange() == mutate() + arrange()), Downsides probably outweigh benefits here at this point..\r\n\r\n\r\nQuoting the 1.1 release notes:\r\n> across(), c_across(), if_any(), and if_all() now require the .cols and .fns arguments. In general, we now recommend that you use pick() instead of an empty across() call or across() with no .fns (e.g. across(c(x, y)). (#6523).\r\n\r\n> Relying on the previous default of .fns = NULL is not yet formally soft-deprecated, because there was no good alternative until now, but it is discouraged and will be soft-deprecated in the next minor release.\r\n\r\nI think that allowing renaming in `pick()` would allow you to soft-deprecate `.fns = NULL` of across and warn on `distinct()` + `across()`.\r\n\r\nEdit: pick() should also allow renaming in` group_by()`", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7028/reactions", #>       "total_count": 1, #> #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 0, #>     "created_at": "2024-05-06T22:32:44Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-05-06T22:37:32Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "This is kind of a weird niche problem. The mutate function is interacting strangely with the ggeffects package when using bind_rows to bind multiple ggeffects objects together then using mutate() to add a column (for both functions ggeffect and ggemmeans). It drops rows for seemingly no reason. There is an easy work around, which is simply to wrap bind_rows in data.frame(), but I figured I'd alert devs to the bug. Anyway, here's a reprex using mtcars.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nrequire(dplyr)\r\nrequire(ggeffects)\r\ndata(mtcars)\r\n# create simple linear models\r\nmodel.fourcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==4,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.sixcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==6,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.eightcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==8,], disp ~ hp)\r\n# doesn't work- drops rows beyond row 7\r\ntest.df <- bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  .id = \"group\") %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n# shows the complete data frame\r\ntest2.df <- data.frame(bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              .id = \"group\")) %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nHere's sessionInfo\r\n\r\n> R version 4.3.2 (2023-10-31 sure if this is intended behaviour but it came up in a recent training session and wasn't what we expected.\r\n\r\n`!` and `-` seem interchangeable when used with `c(...)` but when prefix variables specified to `select` through `...`, `!` doesn't work. Hopefully the below reprex makes this clear.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\n\r\n# Works\r\nstarwars |> \r\n  select(-name, -height)\r\n#> # A tibble: 87 × 12\r\n#>     mass hair_color    skin_color  eye_color birth_year sex    gender  homeworld\r\n#>    <dbl> <chr>         <chr>       <chr>          <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr>    \r\n#>  1    77 blond         fair        blue            19   male   mascul… Tatooine \r\n#>  2    75 <NA>          gold        yellow         112   none   mascul… Tatooine \r\n#>  3    32 <NA>          white, blue red             33   none   mascul… Naboo    \r\n#>  4   136 none          white       yellow          41.9 male   mascul… Tatooine \r\n#>  5    49 brown         light       brown           19   female femini… Alderaan \r\n#>  6   120 brown, grey   light       blue            52   male   mascul… Tatooine \r\n#>  7    75 brown         light       blue            47   female femini… Tatooine \r\n#>  8    32 <NA>          white, red  red             NA   none   mascul… Tatooine \r\n#>  9    84 black         light       brown           24   male   mascul… Tatooine \r\n#> 10    77 auburn, Doesn't work\r\nstarwars |> \r\n  select(!name, !height)\r\n#> # A tibble: 87 × 14\r\n#>    height  mass hair_color    skin_color  eye_color birth_year sex    gender   \r\n#>     <int> <dbl> <chr> "2024-04-25T19:08:52Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Hello,\r\n\r\nThis error was driving me crazy and took me a while to isolate it. \r\nif one wants to use `.data` into a lambda function into across, you cannott index .data with variables created into the lambda function itself, otherwise R will complain that such variable doesn't exist!\r\n\r\nexample: \r\n```r\r\niris |> mutate(\r\n    across(\"Sepal.Length\", \\(x) {\r\n        other_col_name <- \"Sepal.Width\"\r\n        \r\n        other_col_val <- .data[[other_col_name]]\r\n        \r\n        x + other_col_val\r\n    })\r\n)\r\n> Error in .f(.x[[i]], ...) : object 'other_col_name' not found\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhich was driving me crazy, since the variable clearly exists in the scope.\r\n\r\nbut if `other_col_name` is defined outside no problem:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nother_col_name <- \"Sepal.Width\"\r\niris |> mutate(\r\n    across(\"Sepal.Length\", \\(x) {\r\n        \r\n        other_col_val <- .data[[other_col_name]]\r\n        \r\n        x + other_col_val\r\n    })\r\n)\r\n# All fine\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf this is by design and you don't plan to fix it, could be useful to have a clearer error and some extra documentation somewhere!\r\n\r\nThere cases in which for example the index name is defined dynamically based on the x or cur_column() value. Now that I now the issue I'll use pick()[1], unless you have better solutions.", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "I find the docs for `c_across()` imply the requirement for a `rowwise()` call which isn't required.\r\n\r\nHere's a reprex using {palmerpenguins} and another using base R's mtcars\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(\"tidyverse\")\r\nlibrary(\"palmerpenguins\")\r\n\r\npenguins %>% \r\n  group_by(island) %>% \r\n  summarise(max_dimension = max(c_across(ends_with(\"mm\")),\r\n                                na.rm = TRUE))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#>   island    max_dimension\r\n#>   <fct>             <dbl>\r\n#> 1 Biscoe              231\r\n#> 2 Dream               212\r\n#> 3 Torgersen           210\r\n\r\nmtcars %>% \r\n  select(wt, drat, carb, gear) %>% \r\n  group_by(gear) %>% \r\n  summarise(max_value = max(c_across(where(is.numeric))))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#>    gear max_value\r\n#>   <dbl>     <dbl>\r\n#> 1     3      5.42\r\n#> 2     4      4.93\r\n#> 3     5      8\r\n```\r\n\r\nI haven't got a good idea of what I think could be added to the docs so I'm logging the issue now and will try to come back later\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7015/reactions", #> \r\n\r\nWhen using `rename_with()` and ending with duplicated column names, the error message tells us about the transformed, duplicated name and the location of the original columns.\r\n\r\nHowever, it would be much clearer to have the original column names in the error message.\r\n\r\nThe locations are not of much help if `rename_with()` is used in a long pipeline, nor is the transformed name if the function is not well described.\r\n\r\nHere is an example case:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\nletter_sum = function(x){\r\n  x %>% map_chr(~{str_split_1(.x, \"\") %>% map_int(~which(letters==tolower(.x))) %>% sum() %>% as.character()})\r\n}\r\nmtcars %>% rename_with(letter_sum)\r\n#> Error in `rename_with()`:\r\n#> ! Names must be unique.\r\n#> x These names are duplicated:\r\n#>   * \"24\" at locations 4 and 11.\r\n#>   * \"43\" at locations 5 and 6.\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-03-28 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nWhile I admit the transformation is exaggeratedly nonsensical, it shows that the error is not very useful in such cases.\r\n", #>     "closed_by": #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Hello, I've been working on [`tidypolars`](https://tidypolars.etiennebacher.com/) for a few months. It provides the `tidyverse` syntax while using [`polars`](https://rpolars.github.io/) as backend. `polars` provides functions to manipulate dataframes, but also strings, dates, and many more things. Although `tidypolars` doesn't support all functions from the `tidyverse` for now (`lubridate` support in particular is lagging behind), most of `dplyr`, `tidyr`, and `stringr` functions are covered (some arguments might not be supported yet).\r\n\r\nWould you accept adding `tidypolars` to the [list of backends](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr?tab=readme-ov-file#backends) in the README? That would give more visibility to `tidypolars` and would hopefully encourage people to contribute, which would be greatly appreciated given the important number of R / `tidyverse` functions to translate to `polars` syntax.\r\n\r\nHappy to make a PR if so.", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6991/reactions", #> "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Currently this is the message dplyr emits for `summarize()` after `group_by()` with multiple variables.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  group_by(vs, am) |>\r\n  summarize(mean_mpg = mean(mpg))\r\n#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'vs'. You can override using the `.groups`\r\n#> argument.\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#> # Groups:   vs [2]\r\n#>      vs    am mean_mpg\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>\r\n#> 1     0     0     15.0\r\n#> 2     0     1     19.8\r\n#> 3     1     0     20.7\r\n#> 4     1     1     28.4\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-01-29 with [reprex v2.0.2](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI think this message is still confusing and would be more clear if the grouping message was about the output and it explicitly stated `.groups` is an argument in `summarize()`, e.g.,\r\n\r\n```\r\nThe output is grouped by `vs`. You can specify grouping structure of the output using the `.groups` argument in `summarize()`.\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf going this route some things to keep in mind:\r\n\r\n- Maybe \"result\" instead of \"output\" in two places in the message, or change the description of the `.groups` argument to say \"Grouping structure of the output.\" Basically, we should match what we're calling the \"thing\" that the function spits out.\r\n- It would be a nice-to-have if US/UK spelling of the function in the message matched what the spelling in the code that generates the message.\r\n\r\nAn alternative suggestion by @DavisVaughan was\r\n\r\n```\r\nsummarize() has computed your expressions grouped by (foo, bar), and has regrouped the output by (foo).\r\n```\r\n\r\nI think this is an improvement over the current message too, but I'd suggest going with something simpler like the one above.\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2024-01-18T12:40:19Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-01-18T16:40:44Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I believe this is an unexplored performance issue, seemingly relating to dplyr::expand_across\r\n\r\nBenchmarked over a 1000 repetitions of processing ames data; There is a marked difference between direct mutation, and indirect mutation faciliated by across , seemingly both when using `where()` selection, and explicit all_of(c(..)) style selection. The latter speed degredation (of direct listing through all_of(c(...)) I think shows that the issue wont be related to checking properties a la the where() instant. \r\n\r\nI think the performance issue is significant, with direct mutation approx 3x faster than that mediated by across\r\n```\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 9\r\n  expression                                             min   median *`itr/sec`* mem_alloc `gc/sec` n_itr  n_gc total_time\r\n  <bch:expr>                                        <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl> <int> <dbl>   <bch:tm>\r\n1 acrosswhere_func(ames_narrow)                       3.69ms   4.26ms      *219.*    1.75MB     7.70   966    34      4.42s\r\n2 across_all_of_func(ames_narrow)                      3.3ms   3.83ms      *256.*   64.73KB     8.20   969    31      3.78s\r\n3 direct_mutate_func(ames_narrow)                      1.1ms   1.26ms      *766.*   48.59KB     8.52   989    11      1.29s\r\n4 direct_mutate_with_class_detect_func(ames_narrow)   1.22ms   1.36ms      *722.*   71.12KB     8.77   988    12      1.37s\r\n```\r\nI came across and considered whether this was related to #6897; however I believe it is something else.\r\nHere when using across I use the anonymous function syntax as advised.\r\n\r\nfirst a reprex and then my session info...\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(bench)\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\nlibrary(modeldata)\r\noptions(\"lifecycle_verbosity\"=\"error\")\r\n\r\n\r\n(ames_narrow <- ames |> select(1:5))\r\n\r\nnum_op <- mean\r\nchar_op <- identity\r\n\r\nacrosswhere_func <- function(a){\r\n  mutate(a,\r\n         across(where(is.numeric),\\(x){num_op(x)}),\r\n         across(where(is.character)|where(is.factor),\\(x){char_op(x)}))\r\n}\r\n\r\nacross_all_of_func <- function(a){\r\n  mutate(a,\r\n         across(all_of(c(\"Lot_Frontage\",\"Lot_Area\")),\\(x){num_op(x)}),\r\n         across(all_of(c(\"MS_SubClass\",\"MS_Zoning\",\"Street\")),\\(x){char_op(x)}))\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\ndirect_mutate_func <- function(a){\r\n  mutate(a,\r\n         Lot_Frontage = num_op(Lot_Frontage),\r\n         Lot_Area = num_op(Lot_Area),\r\n         MS_SubClass =  char_op(MS_SubClass),\r\n         MS_Zoning =  char_op(MS_Zoning),\r\n         Street = char_op(Street))\r\n}\r\n\r\ndirect_mutate_with_class_detect_func <- function(a){\r\n  \r\n  l <- map_lgl(a,\\(x)is.numeric(x))\r\n  numnames <- names(l[l])\r\n  l <- map_lgl(a,\\(x){is.character(x)|is.factor(x)})\r\n  catnames <- names(l[l])\r\n  \r\n  mutate(a,\r\n         Lot_Frontage = num_op(Lot_Frontage),\r\n         Lot_Area = num_op(Lot_Area),\r\n         MS_SubClass =  char_op(MS_SubClass),\r\n         MS_Zoning =  char_op(MS_Zoning),\r\n         Street = char_op(Street))\r\n}\r\n\r\nb1 <- mark(acrosswhere_func(ames_narrow),\r\n           across_all_of_func(ames_narrow),\r\n           direct_mutate_func(ames_narrow),\r\n           direct_mutate_with_class_detect_func(ames_narrow),iterations = 1000L)\r\n\r\nselect(b1,1:9)\r\n\r\n```\r\nsession info \r\n```\r\nR version 4.2.2 (2022-10-31 ucrt)\r\nPlatform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 (64-bit)\r\nRunning under: Windows 10 x64 (build 19045)\r\n\r\nMatrix products: default\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n[1] LC_COLLATE=English_United Kingdom.utf8  LC_CTYPE=English_United Kingdom.utf8   \r\n[3] LC_MONETARY=English_United Kingdom.utf8 LC_NUMERIC=C                           \r\n[5] LC_TIME=English_United Kingdom.utf8    \r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n [1] modeldata_1.2.0 lubridate_1.9.3 forcats_1.0.0   stringr_1.5.1   dplyr_1.1.4     purrr_1.0.2     readr_2.1.5    \r\n [8] tidyr_1.3.0     tibble_3.2.1    ggplot2_3.4.4   tidyverse_2.0.0 bench_1.1.3    \r\n\r\nloaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n [1] rstudioapi_0.15.0 magrittr_2.0.3    hms_1.1.3         tidyselect_1.2.0  munsell_0.5.0     timechange_0.2.0 \r\n [7] colorspace_2.1-0  R6_2.5.1          rlang_1.1.3       fansi_1.0.4       tools_4.2.2       grid_4.2.2       \r\n[13] gtable_0.3.4      utf8_1.2.3        cli_3.6.2         withr_2.5.0       lifecycle_1.0.3   tzdb_0.4.0       \r\n[19] vctrs_0.6.5       glue_1.6.2        stringi_1.7.8     compiler_4.2.2    pillar_1.9.0      generics_0.1.3   \r\n[25] scales_1.2.1      profmem_0.6.0     pkgconfig_2.0.3 \r\n```", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I have encounter with the necessity of joining several tibbles, which i have nested in a list. This can be easily done using `reduce` function from `purrr` package:\r\n```{r}\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(purrr)\r\n\r\ndf1 <- tibble(\r\n  index = 1:4,\r\n  values = 5:8\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf2 <- tibble(\r\n  index = 2:4,\r\n  first = 6:8\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf3 <- tibble(\r\n  index = 3:4,\r\n  second = 7:8\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf_list <- list(df1, df2, df3)\r\ndf_join <- df_list |> \r\n  reduce(left_join, by = \"index\")\r\n```  \r\n\r\nBut taken into consideration that `bind_cols` from `dplyr` already allows working with lists of data frames I think it could be a great feature the possibility of joining list of dataframes using  `join` functions.\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7083/reactions", #> This seems to only be an issue if the input to `case_when` is length 1 - it errors otherwise.\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n x <- 5\r\n\r\n# silently returns the wrong thing\r\ndplyr::case_when(\r\n    x == 5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    x > 10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> character(0)\r\n\r\n# errors\r\ndplyr::case_match(\r\n    x,\r\n    5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::case_match()`:\r\n#> ! `..2 (right)` must have size 1, not size 0.\r\n\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.1.4'\r\n\r\ny <- 5:7\r\n\r\n# errors out as expected\r\ndplyr::case_when(\r\n    y == 5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    y > 10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = \"other\"\r\n)\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::case_when()`:\r\n#> ! Can't recycle `..1 (left)` (size 3) to match `..2 (right)` (size 0).\r\n\r\n# errors\r\ndplyr::case_match(\r\n    y,\r\n    5 ~ \"hello\",\r\n    10 ~ character(),\r\n    .default = "created_at": "2024-08-28T17:38:43Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-09-02T15:44:47Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "There's currently no quick way to extract both the first and last rows of a grouped data frame. This is useful if, for example, you want to identify the limits from a range of values in an ordered sequence.\r\n\r\nCurrently, the workflow looks something like:\r\n\r\n```\r\n### Option one:\r\n\r\ndf_1 <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        slice_head()\r\n\r\ndf_2 <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        slice_tail()\r\n\r\ndata <- rbind(data_1, data_2)\r\n\r\n### Option two:\r\n\r\ndf <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        filter(row_number()==1 | row_number()==n()) \r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe following code combines existing dplyr functionality to make this operation more intuitive:\r\n```\r\nslice_ends <- function(data){\r\n\r\n    data_1 <- data %>%\r\n        slice_head()\r\n\r\n    data_2 <- data %>%\r\n        slice_tail()\r\n\r\n    rbind(data_1, data_2)\r\n\r\n}\r\n\r\n# To give:\r\n\r\ndf <- df %>%\r\n        group_by(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        arrange(v1, v2) %>%\r\n        slice_ends()\r\n```\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": provided as per #7072. This works correctly inside `filter` but not `mutate`.\r\n\r\n```r\r\niris %>% \r\n  filter(if_any(c(), \\(x) x  > 4000)) # returns no rows as expected\r\n\r\niris %>%\r\n    mutate(z = if_any(c(),  \\(x) x  > 4000)) # incorrectly returns all TRUE\r\n```\r\n\r\nApologies if I misunderstood something.\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": is not a column name in data frame `d`, then `pull(d, x)` attempts to look up the value of `x` in the environment instead of returning NULL or an error as I would expect. \r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\n# Create two env-variables\r\nd <- data.frame(x = \"ex\", y = \"why\")\r\nx <- \"y\"\r\n\r\n# As expected, pulls the data-variable `x`\r\npull(d, x)\r\n\r\n# If name `x` does not exist in `d`,\r\nd <- select(d, -x)\r\n\r\n# Not expected: finds the env-variable `x`, pulls the data-variable `y`\r\npull(d, x)\r\n\r\n# Exactly as if we had written pull(d, y)\r\nidentical(pull(d, x), pull(d, y))\r\n```\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7064/reactions", #> \"dplyr\"))\r\nlibrary(tidyr)\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ntest <- data.frame(\"col1\" = c(1,2,3,4,5,85,74,5,32,6,8), \"col\" = c(\"A\",\"B\",\"B\",\"B\",\"A\",\"C\",\"A\",\"C\",\"B\",\"A\",\"A\"))\r\ntest <- rowwise(test)\r\ntest <- rbind(test, test)\r\nfilter(test, col == \"A\")  #crashes\r\n\r\n# R version 4.4.1 "Sometimes, when doing data wrangling, you need to apply functions not only on multiple columns, but also on multiple pairs of columns. This is what the [`{dplyover}`](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover) package allows with its [`across2()` and `across2x()` functions](https://timteafan.github.io/dplyover/reference/across2.html):\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# remotes::install_github(\"TimTeaFan/dplyover\")\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(dplyover)\r\n\r\niris %>% \r\n  group_by(Species) %>%\r\n  summarise(across2x(starts_with(\"Sepal\"), starts_with(\"Petal\"), cor))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 5\r\n#>   Species   Sepal.Length_Petal.L…¹ Sepal.Length_Petal.W…² Sepal.Width_Petal.Le…³\r\n#>   <fct>                      <dbl>                  <dbl>                  <dbl>\r\n#> 1 setosa                     0.267                  0.278                  0.178\r\n#> 2 versicol…                  0.754                  0.546                  0.561\r\n#> 3 virginica                  0.864                  0.281                  0.401\r\n#> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​Sepal.Length_Petal.Length, ²​Sepal.Length_Petal.Width,\r\n#> #   ³​Sepal.Width_Petal.Length\r\n#> # ℹ 1 more variable: Sepal.Width_Petal.Width <dbl>\r\n\r\ncor(iris[1:50,]$Sepal.Length, iris[1:50,]$Petal.Length)\r\n#> [1] 0.2671758\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-07-17 with [reprex v2.1.0](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\nThe creation of the `{dplyover}` began with this [issue](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4834), which –at that time– recommended putting these features in an adjacent package. \r\n\r\n`{dplyover}` has really saved me and my colleagues a huge amount of time. However, it is not on CRAN, some bugs [[1](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/21), [2](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/23)] have been found, enhancement in the `{dplyr}` package are [not currently supported](https://github.com/TimTeaFan/dplyover/issues/1), and the last commit is 3 years old.\r\n\r\nDo you think these really useful functions could be included in the `{dplyr}` package? "created_at": "2024-07-03T23:56:10Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-07-05T13:04:02Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "## Problem\r\n\r\nThanks @AMDraghici for your suggestions!\r\n\r\nFor example, in `bind_rows`, if the first input is a `data.table`, the output table can have corrupt indexing due to how the underlying `dplyr_reconstruct` function deals with the attributes of the two inputs\r\n\r\n## Reprex\r\n\r\nThe example below shows that the index attribute can be incorrect for the output. \r\n\r\n```r\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(5, 2:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"c\") # Create a data.table\r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil. This is necessary for the subset error below to happen in data.table. But it is not necessary to re-produce the corrupted index. \r\n> a[cola == 4] # Give data.table a secondary index (\"cola\" column) by auto-indexing\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$index # The secondary index is set correctly\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, colb = 2, colc=3, cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::bind_rows(list(a,b))\r\n> \r\n> combined # combined is a data.table, with 5 rows\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola      colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     5 0.5535855 0.6024416      c\r\n2:     2 0.3407051 0.9291365      c\r\n3:     3 0.5007208 0.6823528      c\r\n4:     4 0.1495679 0.6097216      c\r\n5:    -1 2.0000000 3.0000000      d\r\n> \r\n> attributes(combined)$index # Wrong! length of secondary index is only 4\r\ninteger(0)\r\nattr(,\"__cola\")\r\n[1] 2 3 4 1\r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 4 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold # Wrong! The last row of combined should be returned\r\n> combined\r\nIndex: <cola>\r\n    cola       colb      colc   cold\r\n   <num>      <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     1 0.83105427 0.4214379      c\r\n2:     2 0.05702599 0.1354883      c\r\n3:     3 0.63866251 0.1644736      c\r\n4:     4 0.21441544 0.2198251      c\r\n5:    -1 2.00000000 3.0000000      d\r\n```\r\n## Cause\r\n\r\nIn the `bind_rows` function, `dplyr_reconstruct` is used to set attributes for the output dataframe. \r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/R/bind-rows.R#L79\r\n\r\n```r\r\nout <- dplyr_reconstruct(out, first)\r\n```\r\nLooking at the `dplyr_reconstruct` function, it is essentially giving all attributes other than `names` and `row.names` in `template_` to `data`.\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/be36acf9c86e5d4c3d97f97b8d3999b713123392/src/reconstruct.cpp#L36 \r\n\r\nIn the case above, all attributes of `first` (which has four rows), including index are given to `out`, which has five rows. This causes the problem. \r\n\r\n## Impact\r\n\r\nBecause the `data.table` produced by `bind_rows` has corrupted secondary index, the filter functionality of `data.table` is skipping some rows when filtering by the index column. \r\nAlso, I found that this problem is not limited to `bind_rows`. Other `dplyr` functions that calls `dplyr_reconstruct` can result in data.tables with corrupted secondary index. For example, the `full_join` function can also produce unexpected results due to corrupted secondary index.  \r\n\r\n```\r\n> a <- data.table::data.table(cola = c(1:4), colb = runif(4), colc= runif(4), cold = \"d\")\r\n> \r\n> attributes(a)$.internal.selfref <- new(\"externalptr\") # Set pointer to nil\r\n> a[cola == 3]\r\n       cola         colb         colc      cold\r\n   <int>     <num>     <num> <char>\r\n1:     3 0.9968646 0.8137836      d\r\n> \r\n> b <- data.table::data.table(cola = -1, cole = \"e\")\r\n> \r\n> combined <- dplyr::full_join(a, b, by = \"cola\")\r\n> \r\n> combined[cola==-1]\r\nEmpty data.table (0 rows and 5 cols): cola,colb,colc,cold,cole\r\n```", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "site_admin": false #>     }, #>     "labels": [], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 0, #>     "created_at": "2024-06-26T19:48:59Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-06-26T19:48:59Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "See https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7044\r\n\r\nIn particular, note that `arrange(df, x)` will sort `x` using the C locale if it is a character vector. But `arrange(df, -desc(x))` (i.e. invert the `desc()` call, giving you the original order in theory) will sort `x` using the user's locale.\r\n\r\nNormally a call like `desc(x)` is recognized and we don't even actually call `desc()` under the hood, we translate it to a `\"desc\"` value for the `directions` argument of `vec_order_radix()`, but in this case the `-` interferes and we actually evaluate the call.\r\n\r\nThat ends up calling `desc()` which does `-xtfrm(x)`, and `xtfrm()` ends up using `base::order(x)`, utilizing the user's locale.\r\n\r\nI don't think we should remove usage of `xtfrm()` in `desc()`, since that is a generic that people have probably written S3 methods for, but maybe we can have special behavior for unclassed character vectors where it utilized `vec_rank()` instead (which uses the C locale)? It would not be a perfect fix, but it may be good enough.", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7045/reactions", #> "created_at": "2024-06-12T05:52:35Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-06-12T05:52:35Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Should we guarantee that the functions used in a rowwise `mutate()` or `summarize()` or `reframe()` always see length-one input? This is currently the case for everything but empty input, which creates a corner case to be worked around in user code. The example below shows `mutate()`, but the behavior is very similar for `summarize()` and `reframe()`\r\n\r\n``` r\r\noptions(conflicts.policy = list(warn = FALSE))\r\n\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1L) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\ntibble(a = 1:3) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> [1] 1\r\n#> [1] 2\r\n#> [1] 3\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#>       a `print(a)`\r\n#>   <int>      <int>\r\n#> 1     1          1\r\n#> 2     2          2\r\n#> 3     3          3\r\n```\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n\r\n# Should this print `NA_integer_` ?\r\ntibble(a = integer()) |>\r\n  rowwise() |>\r\n  mutate(print(a))\r\n#> integer(0)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 × 2\r\n#> # Rowwise: \r\n#> # ℹ 2 variables: a <int>, print(a) <int>\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2024-06-12 "created_at": "2024-06-02T23:02:29Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-06-03T19:17:48Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "draft": false, #>     "pull_request": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/pulls/7038", #>       "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/7038", #>       "diff_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/7038.diff", #>       "patch_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/7038.patch", #>       "merged_at": {} #>     }, #>     "body": "Hi @hadley and @DavisVaughan,\r\n\r\nThis merge request aims to align the mutate functionality with that of transmute. Presently, the documentation states that the equivalent of transmute is mutate(.keep=\"none\"). However, it's important to note that this function retains the column order, unlike transmute.\r\n\r\nAfter reviewing the bug reported here: https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6861, I concur that there should be a fifth variant of keep, named \"transmute.\"\r\n\r\nThis proposal should also be implemented in the following tidyverse libraries:\r\n- [ ] [dtplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dtplyr)  \r\n- [ ] [dbplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr):  https://github.com/tidyverse/dbplyr/pull/1508\r\n\r\nAnd in the following third party libraries:\r\n- [ ] [duckplyr](https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr): https://github.com/duckdblabs/duckplyr/pull/176\r\n- [ ] [arrow](https://github.com/apache/arrow/r)\r\n- [ ] [tidypolars](https://github.com/etiennebacher/tidypolars)\r\n\r\nThis change opens the possibility of un-superseded transmute. For example, you could implement that when a user calls transmute, it internally executes mutate(.keep=\"transmute\"). This would greatly benefit veteran users who have extensively used transmute in their projects. Additionally, it improves code readability, as a simple transmute call is clearer than mutate(.keep=\"transmute\").\r\n\r\nBelow I leave an example comparing transmute with mutate(.keep = \"transmute\")\r\n\r\n```\r\nexample <- tibble(\r\n  group = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\"),\r\n  old = c(1, 2, 3, 4)\r\n)\r\n\r\n# transmute --------------------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% transmute(\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") --------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% mutate(\r\n  .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n  group,\r\n  new = old * 2,\r\n  old\r\n)\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         2     1\r\n2 a         4     2\r\n3 b         6     3\r\n4 b         8     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + transmute ---------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  transmute(\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# group_by + mutate(.keep = \"transmute\") ---------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>% \r\n  group_by(group) %>% \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n) %>% \r\n ungroup()\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n# mutate(.keep = \"transmute\", by = ...) ----------------------------------------\r\n\r\nexample %>%  \r\n  mutate(\r\n    .keep = \"transmute\",\r\n    .by = \"group\",\r\n    new = sum(old),\r\n    old\r\n  )\r\n\r\n# A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n  group   new   old\r\n  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n1 a         3     1\r\n2 a         3     2\r\n3 b         7     3\r\n4 b         7     4\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nRegards,\r\n\r\n", #>     "closed_by": {}, #> #>     "number": 7028, #>     "title": "FR: allow `pick()` to rename in `distinct()` + some thoughts about `arrange()` allowing renaming.", #>     "user": { #>       "login": "olivroy", #>       "id": 52606734, #>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjUyNjA2NzM0", #>       "avatar_url": "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/52606734?v=4", #>       "gravatar_id": "", #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy", #>       "html_url": "https://github.com/olivroy", #>       "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/followers", #>       "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/starred{/owner}{/repo}", #>       "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/subscriptions", #>       "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/orgs", #>       "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/repos", #>       "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/events{/privacy}", #>       "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/olivroy/received_events", #>       "type": "User", #>       "site_admin": false #>     }, #>     "labels": [], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2024-05-18T17:37:23Z", #>     "updated_at": "2024-08-20T14:46:11Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "This would be useful in packages to avoid cran warnings as `pick()` is the new preferred way.\r\n\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\noptions(lifecycle_verbosity = \"error\")\r\nmtcars <- utils::head(mtcars, n = 6)\r\n# distinct -----------\r\n# renaming generally makes a lot of sense, as distinct is like `transmute(...)` + `distinct()`\r\n# consider this in EDA\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = vs)\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\n# as it is equivalent to: (to avoid cran warnings)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(x = .data$vs)\r\n# Before dplyr 1.1, `across()` was recommended, which works, but .fns = NULL is soft-deprecated.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# The alternative when you may not know variable names in a package\r\n# with `pick()` should therefore work too, but errors.\r\n# I think it should work\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `distinct()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n# Similarly:\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  distinct(pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n\r\n# I would expect distinct() and transmute()  + distinct() to be same as above (and it is!) ---\r\n# transmute() is still very useful as it is mutate + select in a single call)\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#>            x\r\n#> Mazda RX4  0\r\n#> Datsun 710 1\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(x = .data$vs) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n# I think this should be allowed.\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  transmute(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))) |> \r\n  distinct()\r\n#> Error in `transmute()`:\r\n#> ℹ In argument: `pick(all_of(c(x = \"vs\")))`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nNow comes `arrange()`...\r\n\r\n## arrange() \r\n\r\nWhile I believe `distinct()` should accept renaming under any circonstances, I believe that accepting renaming in `arrange()` is inconsistent, as `arrange()` ignores it silently. renaming (or attempt to do so) should error in all cases for `arrange()`. \r\n\r\nHowever, it behaves exactly the same as `distinct()`. (so it is consistent in that sense, but ignores )\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# arrange() is same as distinct() but silently ignores renaming...\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(x = .data$vs)\r\n# no x variable\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(across(all_of(c(x = \"vs\"))))\r\n# this rightfully errors!\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(pick(x = \"vs\"))\r\n#> Error in `arrange()`:\r\n#>  ℹ In argument: `..1 = pick(x = \"vs\")`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `pick()`:\r\n#> ! Can't rename variables in this context.\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe a soft-deprecation warning would be desirable for attempting to rename in arrange()\r\nSomething like names ignored, use unnamed, or remove name, or create this variable with mutate() to keep it.\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\n#  A beginner may think that this will create the variable as nothing is stopping them.\r\ny <- mtcars |> arrange(x = vs, y = desc(disp))\r\n\r\n## later tries to access the variable and gets a warning or even worse. This confusing data frame.\r\n\r\ny |> mutate(z = y **2) # gets very bad output!\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n# Suggestions for signaling that `arrange()` ignores renaming.\r\n\r\n1. (preferred) soft-deprecation warning\r\n \r\nsomething like: named input is ignored in arrange(). Please omit them.\r\nin all_of(named_external_selection)  the adjustment required would just be all_of(unname(named_external_selection))\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nx |> arrange(new_var = var)\r\n# now\r\nx |> arrange(var)\r\n```\r\n\r\nif you want to create a new variable or rename, use `rename()` or `mutate()`, as arrange silently ignores names provided.\r\n\r\n\r\n## using the case of tidyselect deprecation of external selection as an example\r\n\r\nit seems pretty similar as the deprecation of `select(.data$vs)` in favour of `select(\"vs\")` + requiring any_of() all_of(). it ended up just increasing\r\ngeneral consitency of code base, and improve clarity.\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Before when you read this in someone else's code (i.e. with no context)\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(vs)\r\n# you had no idea if the data had a `vs` column, or `vs` was an external vector\r\n# the alternative made everything much clearer.\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  select(all_of(vs))\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nMy proposed change would force users to remove this potentially misleading code\r\n have the benefit that no one would question if the resulting data frame has a `x` column or not.\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6980 would be addressed automatically as part of this idea. i.e no longer allowing named selection would act a bit like a `check_dots_used()` condition\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# before\r\nmtcars |>\r\n  arrange(x = vs)\r\n# this code is clearer about what it does (and gives the same result as above)\r\n# proposed\r\nmtcars |> \r\n  arrange(vs)\r\n```\r\n\r\n2. Breaking change (respect renaming in arrange() i.e. arrange() == mutate() + arrange()), Downsides probably outweigh benefits here at this point..\r\n\r\n\r\nQuoting the 1.1 release notes:\r\n> across(), c_across(), if_any(), and if_all() now require the .cols and .fns arguments. In general, we now recommend that you use pick() instead of an empty across() call or across() with no .fns (e.g. across(c(x, y)). (#6523).\r\n\r\n> Relying on the previous default of .fns = NULL is not yet formally soft-deprecated, because there was no good alternative until now, but it is discouraged and will be soft-deprecated in the next minor release.\r\n\r\nI think that allowing renaming in `pick()` would allow you to soft-deprecate `.fns = NULL` of across and warn on `distinct()` + `across()`.\r\n\r\nEdit: pick() should also allow renaming in` group_by()`", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/7028/reactions", #>       "total_count": 1, #> "2024-05-06T22:37:32Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "This is kind of a weird niche problem. The mutate function is interacting strangely with the ggeffects package when using bind_rows to bind multiple ggeffects objects together then using mutate() to add a column (for both functions ggeffect and ggemmeans). It drops rows for seemingly no reason. There is an easy work around, which is simply to wrap bind_rows in data.frame(), but I figured I'd alert devs to the bug. Anyway, here's a reprex using mtcars.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nrequire(dplyr)\r\nrequire(ggeffects)\r\ndata(mtcars)\r\n# create simple linear models\r\nmodel.fourcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==4,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.sixcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==6,], disp ~ hp)\r\nmodel.eightcyl <- lm(data = mtcars[mtcars$cyl==8,], disp ~ hp)\r\n# doesn't work- drops rows beyond row 7\r\ntest.df <- bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                  .id = \"group\") %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n# shows the complete data frame\r\ntest2.df <- data.frame(bind_rows(\"FourCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.fourcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"SixCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.sixcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              \"EightCyl\" = ggemmeans(model.eightcyl, terms = \"hp\"),\r\n                              .id = \"group\")) %>% mutate(pred2 = predicted/10)\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nHere's sessionInfo\r\n\r\n> R version 4.3.2 (2023-10-31 "2024-04-25T19:08:52Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Hello,\r\n\r\nThis error was driving me crazy and took me a while to isolate it. \r\nif one wants to use `.data` into a lambda function into across, you cannott index .data with variables created into the lambda function itself, otherwise R will complain that such variable doesn't exist!\r\n\r\nexample: \r\n```r\r\niris |> mutate(\r\n    across(\"Sepal.Length\", \\(x) {\r\n        other_col_name <- \"Sepal.Width\"\r\n        \r\n        other_col_val <- .data[[other_col_name]]\r\n        \r\n        x + other_col_val\r\n    })\r\n)\r\n> Error in .f(.x[[i]], ...) : object 'other_col_name' not found\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhich was driving me crazy, since the variable clearly exists in the scope.\r\n\r\nbut if `other_col_name` is defined outside no problem:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nother_col_name <- \"Sepal.Width\"\r\niris |> mutate(\r\n    across(\"Sepal.Length\", \\(x) {\r\n        \r\n        other_col_val <- .data[[other_col_name]]\r\n        \r\n        x + other_col_val\r\n    })\r\n)\r\n# All fine\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf this is by design and you don't plan to fix it, could be useful to have a clearer error and some extra documentation somewhere!\r\n\r\nThere cases in which for example the index name is defined dynamically based on the x or cur_column() value. Now that I now the issue I'll use pick()[1], unless you have better solutions.", #>     "closed_by": {}, #>     "reactions": { #>       "url":
